name: Shirley Glass
statements: Who is your target audience?
I'm saying that you're in danger of appealing to a narrow range of listeners if it becomes a little too-- I don't know what word to use.
Artsy, yeah.
Now that Hugh Grant is such a big star, and everybody who sees you or sees your picture thinks how much you look like Hugh Grant, that fires up that TV thing again in me.
Well, gosh, wouldn't they want this wonderful humanistic, intelligent reporter who looks like Hugh Grant?
What's the theme for this week?
That's very interesting, because I just did an interview this morning with a newspaper reporter about roman--
--mance, romantic love. And people's expectations about relationships. And one of the things I believe is that there are a lot of people who are good at beginnings, but they're not good at middles.

It means that they like the beginning, where there's all this idealization and romantic projections. And the other person can be who they think they should be, rather than who they are. And when they get to the middle phase--
--where there's more of a reality-based relationship, they run away from it because it's not as exciting.
So you are good at middles.
That's good. That's good because practically all of life is the middle.
Are we going to get a tape of this since we're outside the Chicago listening area?
OK.
Hello?
Oh, hi, Ira.
Fine. Can you hold on a second?
Hi.
Yeah.
Yeah.
What about?
Hm. Do I have any advice? Well, can I ask another question?
